data.title: Conclusions
data.meta_description: Reflecting on the situation of portraiture in the early twentieth century, Jean-Luc Nancy foregrounds its persistence. Portraits continued to be sought after when new and destructive forces traversed the human subject, when the subject was no longer “the...
data.text: Reflecting on the situation of portraiture in the early twentieth century, Jean-Luc Nancy foregrounds its persistence. Portraits continued to be sought after when new and destructive forces traversed the human subject, when the subject was no longer “the subject of a self-certainty or of a ‘humanism’ gathering the properties of the divine into man” (Nancy in Portrait, Fordham University Press, New York, 2018, 91), and when “the possibility of a face-to-face of the ‘self’” collapsed (Nancy in Portrait, Fordham University Press, New York, 2018, 86).
